ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The lecture was solely conducted through live virtual lectures.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: You learn the basics of Hong Kong's history chronologically! After this class, you would have a deep understanding of the region to engage in challenging conversations.
I learned about key points in the history of Hong Kong and Shenzhen and developed my abilities to analyze primary and secondary sources.

I learned about Hong Kong-China border history, starting from the late 1800s to the present. We mostly discussed the environment in Hong Kong, the citizens, and localist identity. While we talked about contextual historical background at times, this course does not talk about the Opium Wars or what led to British Conquest. We mainly start after British colonization and go to the 2020 Hong Kong protests.
I learned more about Hong Kong & South Chinese history. I also learned more about writing papers based on primary sources and forming good arguments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: There were only a few students in the class, which gave everyone a lot of opportunities to speak and engage with the materials. You learn a lot from Professor Ho, but the other students also play an important role in your engagement with the content. You really learn a LOT in this class, so be prepared for that. Weakness: There were times when the class just became quiet, and Professor Ho had to step in and try to direct the conversation. I think that's just a product of virtual setting. It might be solved in an in-person setting with more students.

The syllabus is well-organized. I enjoyed reading books and articles in other disciplines such as sociology and anthropology. Writing essays based on primary sources has been a great learning experience as well. This seminar has been one of the best I have taken at Yale as everyone is devoted to class discussion.

I enjoyed the seminar style of the course. It was helpful to receive individualized feedback and to learn from my peers. Moreover, a lot of the primary sources that we examined were very niche and unavailable publicly, so it was cool that my classmates and I had access to such material. The main thing I would have appreciated more of was clarity regarding writing expectations. I felt like I went into the first essay blind and din't know what had been expected of me until after going over my comments. It would have been helpful to receive the rubric beforehand. Moreover, there were times where I felt like some of the course readings were a little repetitive and could have been cut down and/or replaced with something else. Furthermore, while we started examining pictures, videos, and podcasts towards the end of the course, it would have been interesting to look at more diverse formats of primary sources earlier on.

On the whole, the course was engaging and the readings & primary sources were well selected. However, there were a few weeks when we had an enormous amount of reading assigned, to the point where it was unfeasible for me to finish all of it in addition to my other coursework (but I guess this is a history seminar, so kind of typical)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is helpful to write three short essays given the relative difficulty in completely finding sources online.

I thought that the five minute break in the middle of the two-hour seminar was very helpful and allowed me to re-energize myself for the second half of the class. I was also glad that all resources and course materials were available online or via Yale's course reserves. This made the class material extremely accessible, and I feel like this aspect of the course should even be preserved during non-virtual times.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if you are interested in the topic. Look at the syllabus beforehand to get an idea of the contents. I will warn you though that there's a decent amount of readings, and you can't skip them. My seminar had six students, and so you had to know the material pretty well to discuss it.
Absolutely! Especially for anyone interested in Chinese history and/or want to learn more about Hong Kong from its past to present.

Yes, but mainly if you have an interest in East Asian studies. I enjoyed learning about the history of Hong Kong and Hong Kong-China relations. I felt like the material was put together thoughtfully and enjoyed many of the readings. However, I feel like students who are interested in general history, rather than region-specific events, may find that this course isn't for them.
